Enseñanzas deportivas. Enseñanzas artísticas superiores. f) Estudios religiosos superiores. Cursos de acceso y cursos de preparación para las pruebas de acceso a la formación profesional y cursos de formación específicos para el acceso a los ciclos formativos de Código seguro de Verificación : GEN-afed-f11a-2acf-695d-4be9-51c8-2c08-5869 | Puede verificar la integridad de este documento en la siguiente dirección : https://sede.administracion.gob.es/pagSedeFront/servicios

deepseek-chat.text:
The Spanish Ministry of Education and Vocational Training has announced general grants for the 2023-2024 academic year. These grants are open-ended, meaning there is no fixed number of beneficiaries, and are available for a wide range of post-compulsory and higher education programs.

Eligible studies include secondary education (Bachillerato), intermediate and advanced vocational training, professional and advanced arts education, sports studies, higher religious studies, official language school courses, access courses for vocational training, and Basic Vocational Training. For university students, grants are available for official bachelor's and master's degree programs, including those at military and police university centers, as well as access courses for students over 25 and certain complementary credits. Studies for doctoral degrees, specializations, and university-specific degrees are not included.

The financial award consists of several components. A fixed amount of 300 euros is provided as a basic grant. Students may also receive a fixed income-based component of 1,700 euros and a residence supplement of 2,500 euros if they must live away from home to study. A variable amount, starting from a minimum of 60 euros, is calculated based on family income and assets. Additionally, an excellence supplement is awarded based on the previous year's average grade: 50 euros for an average of 8.00 to 8.49, 75 euros for 8.50 to 8.99, 100 euros for 9.00 to 9.49, and 125 euros for an average of 9.50 or higher. Students from the Balearic and Canary Islands are eligible for specific geographical supplements.

To qualify, applicants must meet strict academic, economic, and asset requirements. Academic requirements vary: university students must pass a minimum of 60 credits for full-time studies or 30 credits for part-time studies in the previous year, with specific pass rate percentages required by field of study (e.g., 90% for Arts, 65% for Sciences). For new university students, a minimum university access grade of 5.00 is required. Family income must not exceed established thresholds, which vary based on the number of family members. There are also limits on the value of urban properties, rural land, and financial capital. Several deductions are applied to the family income calculation for circumstances such as having a large family, disability, being an orphan, or having a sibling also studying at university away from home.

Students with a disability equal to or greater than 65% have a reduced course load requirement and receive a 50% increase in the fixed components of the grant. The application period for all students, both university and non-university, was from March 27, 2023, to May 17, 2023.

deepseek-reasoner.text:
For the 2023-2024 academic year, the Spanish Ministry of Education offers grants for a wide range of post-compulsory and higher education programs. These include Baccalaureate, intermediate and advanced Vocational Training, professional and higher arts education, sports studies, higher religious studies, official language school courses, and access courses for vocational training. For university studies, grants are available for official Bachelor's and Master's degree programs at Spanish institutions. PhD programs, specialized studies, and university-specific degrees are not included.

The financial award comprises fixed and variable components. The fixed part includes a basic grant of 300 euros, a residence supplement of 2,500 euros for students who must live away from home, and a fixed income-based grant of 1,700 euros. A variable minimum amount of 60 euros is also guaranteed for eligible students. Additional academic excellence grants range from 50 to 125 euros, based on the student's average grade from the previous year (e.g., 100 euros for a 9.0 to 9.49 average).

Eligibility is primarily based on family income and assets, which must fall below specific annual thresholds. These thresholds vary depending on family size. For example, for a family of four, the limit to qualify for the full fixed-income grant is 21,054 euros. There are also limits on the value of urban properties, rural land, and financial assets. Significant deductions from the calculated family income are applied for special circumstances, such as being part of a large family (525 or 800 euros), having a disability (1,811 to 4,000 euros), or in cases of orphanhood or single-parent families.

Academic requirements must be met. New university students need a minimum university access grade of 5.00. Continuing university students must pass a required percentage of credits, which varies by field (e.g., 90% for Arts and Humanities, 65% for Sciences and Engineering). Full-time students must enroll in at least 60 credits, and part-time students in at least 30 credits. Students with a disability of 65% or more have reduced course load requirements.

Students studying in the Canary Islands, Balearic Islands, Ceuta, or Melilla are eligible for supplementary allowances, ranging from 442 to 937 euros, to offset higher costs. The standard application period was from March 27 to May 17, 2023.

deepseek-chat.text:
This is a summary of the official Spanish government grants (Becas MEC) for the 2021-2022 academic year. The grants are available for a wide range of post-compulsory and higher education programs. These include high school (Bachillerato), vocational training (FP), professional and higher arts education, sports studies, higher religious studies, official language school courses, and access courses for vocational training. For university students, grants cover official Bachelor's and Master's degree programs, preparation courses for university access for those over 25, and specific complementary credits. Grants for PhD programs, specialization studies, or university-specific degrees are not included.

The financial award is composed of several parts. All eligible students receive a basic grant of 300 euros. A fixed amount based on family income can be 1,700 euros, and a residence supplement for those studying away from home is 1,600 euros. There is also a variable amount with a minimum of 60 euros, which increases based on family income. High-achieving students with a grade point average between 8.00 and 9.49 can receive an excellence supplement ranging from 50 to 100 euros, and those with a 9.50 or above receive 125 euros. Students from the Balearic or Canary Islands may be eligible for additional supplements for insularity and travel.

Eligibility depends on strict academic and economic requirements. For university students, a minimum of 60 credits must be passed in a full-time course, or 30 credits for part-time studies. Minimum required grades vary by field of study, ranging from 65% to 90% of credits passed. For new university students, a minimum university access grade of 5.00 is required. Family income must fall below one of three published thresholds, which vary based on the number of family members. There are also limits on family assets, including urban properties, rural land, and financial capital. Several deductions are applied to the family income calculation for special circumstances, such as having a large family, a family member with a disability, or being an orphan.

Students with a disability equal to or greater than 65% have reduced course load requirements and are eligible for a 50% increase in the tuition grant component. The application deadlines were 30 September 2021 for non-university students and 14 October 2021 for university students, with a final deadline for all applications on 31 December 2021.

deepseek-reasoner.text:

Eligible studies include two main categories. First, post-secondary non-university studies: Baccalaureate years 1 and 2; Basic, Middle, and Higher Grade Vocational Training; professional and higher artistic education; higher sports education; higher religious studies; official language school courses; and specific access courses for vocational training. Second, university studies: official Bachelor's and Master's degrees, access courses for those over 25, and specific complementary credits. Doctoral studies and university-specific degrees are excluded.

Students who must live away from home to study may receive a residence supplement of 1,600 euros. There is also a variable amount, with a minimum of 60 euros, calculated based on the student's financial situation. Additionally, an excellence supplement is available for university students with a high grade point average: 50 euros for an average between 8.00 and 8.49, 75 euros for 8.50 to 8.99, 100 euros for 9.00 to 9.49, and 125 euros for an average of 9.50 or higher. Extra supplements are available for students from the Canary Islands, Balearic Islands, Ceuta, and Melilla.

To qualify, students must meet specific academic and economic requirements. Academic requirements differ: for university access, a minimum grade of 5.00 is needed. Current university students must pass a percentage of credits, which varies by field from 65% to 90%, and must be enrolled in a minimum of 60 credits for full-time or 30 credits for part-time status. Family income and assets must not exceed established thresholds, which vary based on the number of family members. Significant deductions from the calculated family income are applied for special circumstances, such as having a large family, a family member with a disability, or being in a single-parent family.

deepseek-chat.text:
The Spanish Ministry of Education has announced its general grant and scholarship program for the 2025-2026 academic year. Applications are open from March 24, 2025, at 8:00 AM (peninsular time) until May 14, 2025.

These grants are available for a wide range of post-compulsory and higher education programs. This includes high school (Bachillerato), vocational training cycles (both intermediate and advanced), professional arts and sports studies, university-level arts, and official university degrees and master's programs. Studies must lead to an official Spanish qualification.

Financial awards consist of several components. There is a basic grant of 300 euros. A fixed amount based on family income can be 1,700 euros, and a residence supplement for students living away from home is 2,700 euros. A variable amount, with a minimum of 60 euros, is calculated based on the applicant's specific financial situation. Additional supplements are available for students in the Balearic and Canary Islands to help with higher costs, and for academic excellence. The excellence supplement ranges from 50 to 125 euros, based on the student's average grade from the previous year, starting from an 8.0 average.

Eligibility is primarily determined by family income and assets, which must fall below specific thresholds. These thresholds vary depending on the number of family members. For example, for a family of four, the annual income limit is 22,107 euros for the most favorable threshold. There are also limits on the value of urban properties, rural land, and financial assets.

Academic requirements must also be met. For university students, a minimum of 60 credits must be passed in a full-time year, or 30 for part-time study. The required pass rate varies by field of study, from 65% in Sciences and Engineering to 90% in Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences. First-year university students need a university entrance exam score of at least 5.0.

Significant deductions are applied to the family income calculation for special circumstances. These include deductions for large families, students with disabilities (from 1,811 euros upwards), orphans, single-parent families, and when a sibling is also studying at university away from home. Students with a disability of 65% or more have reduced academic load requirements and can receive increased grant amounts.

Prospective applicants should consult the official BOE publication for complete details and use the official government portal to apply within the stated deadlines.

Eligible studies include high school (Bachillerato), vocational training (middle and higher grade), professional and higher arts education, sports studies, higher religious studies, official language school courses, access courses for vocational training, and Basic Vocational Training cycles. For university students, grants are available for official Bachelor's and Master's degree programs, access courses for those over 25, and specific complementary credits. Studies for doctorates, specializations, or university-specific degrees are not included.

The financial aid consists of several components. A basic grant of 300 euros is available. There is a fixed amount for general expenses of 1,700 euros and a residency supplement of 1,600 euros for students who must live away from home. A variable grant starts at a minimum of 60 euros. Additionally, an excellence supplement is awarded based on the previous year's average grade: 50 euros for an average between 8.00 and 8.49, 75 euros for 8.50 to 8.99, 100 euros for 9.00 to 9.49, and 125 euros for an average of 9.50 or higher.

Eligibility depends on meeting specific academic and economic thresholds. Academic requirements vary: university students must pass a minimum of 60 credits for full-time studies or 30 credits for part-time studies in the previous year, with required pass rates differing by field of study (from 65% in Sciences and Engineering to 90% in Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences). New university students need a minimum university access grade of 5.00. Family income and assets must not exceed established limits, which vary based on the number of family members. There are three income thresholds (Umbral 1, 2, and 3), with specific euro limits for households of one to eight members. Asset limits include a maximum value for urban and rustic properties and a limit on financial capital.

Several deductions can be applied to the family income calculation, including amounts for large families, students with disabilities, orphans, single-parent families, and when a sibling is also studying at university away from home. Students with a disability equal to or greater than 65% have a reduced course load requirement and receive a 50% increase in the full enrollment grant component. Students studying in the Canary Islands, Balearic Islands, Ceuta, or Melilla are eligible for additional insular supplements.

The application period for all students, both university and non-university, was from March 30, 2022, to May 12, 2022.

Students with disabilities of 65% or higher qualify for reduced course loads and a 50% grant increase for full enrollment.

deepseek-reasoner.text:
The Spanish Ministry of Education has announced grants for the 2024-2025 academic year. These grants support a wide range of post-obligatory and higher education programs, including baccalaureate, vocational training, artistic and sports studies, language courses, and university degrees and master's programs. PhD studies and proprietary titles are excluded.

Financial support includes several fixed components: a basic grant of 300 euros, a fixed income grant of 1,700 euros, and a residence grant of 2,500 euros for students living away from home. A variable grant starts at a minimum of 60 euros, and excellence grants are awarded based on academic performance: 50 euros for an average grade of 8.00 to 8.49, 75 euros for 8.50 to 8.99, 100 euros for 9.00 to 9.49, and 125 euros for 9.50 or higher.

Eligibility depends on family income and patrimony. Income thresholds vary by the number of family members; for example, for a single-member family, the thresholds are 8,843 euros, 13,898 euros, and 14,818 euros. Patrimony limits include 42,900 euros for urban properties, 42,900 euros for rural constructions, 13,130 euros per member for rural properties, and 1,700 euros for movable capital.

Academic requirements must be met. Full-time students must enroll in at least 60 credits, or 30 credits for partial enrollment. University access requires a minimum grade of 5.00, and specific credit pass rates are set by field, such as 90% for Arts and Humanities and 65% for Sciences.

Additional benefits are available. Insular supplements provide extra funding for students in islands, with amounts ranging from 442 to 937 euros. Income deductions apply for circumstances like large families, disabilities, orphans, and single-parent families, with amounts up to 4,000 euros for severe disabilities in university students. Students with disabilities of 65% or more can have reduced course loads and a 50% increase in the full enrollment grant.

The application period for all students runs from March 19, 2024, to May 10, 2024. For complete details, refer to the official BOE document.
deepseek-reasoner.reasoning_content:
First, I am tasked with writing a clear and informative summary in English for a student interested in applying. The summary should be based on the provided data from the official BOE (Boletín Oficial del Estado) about Spanish education grants for the academic year 2024-2025. The summary must be professional, cover all relevant financial and requirement details, and be easy to read.

Strict rules: Use only plain text. No markdown, no bold, italics, tables, or symbols like '#' or '---'. So, I need to write in plain English without any formatting.

Key elements from the data:

1. **Academic Programs**: Various post-obligatory and non-university higher education, including baccalaureate, vocational training, artistic and sports studies, religious studies, language courses, access courses, and basic vocational training cycles. Also, university studies for degrees and master's, but not PhD or proprietary titles.

2. **Financial Details**:

   - Fixed income grant: 1,700.00 euros

   - Residence grant: 2,500.00 euros

   - Basic grant: 300.00 euros

   - Variable minimum grant: 60.00 euros

   - Excellence grants: Based on average grade, from 50 to 125 euros for grades 8.00 and above.

3. **Income Thresholds**: Depend on the number of family members. For example, for 1 member, thresholds are 8,843; 13,898; 14,818 euros. I need to explain this clearly without a table.

4. **Patrimony Thresholds**: Limits for urban properties, rural constructions, rural properties per member, and movable capital.

5. **Academic Requirements**:

   - Credits for full-time: 60

   - Credits for partial enrollment: 30

   - Minimum grade for university access: 5.00

   - Percentage of credits passed by field of study: e.g., Arts and Humanities 90%, Sciences 65%, etc.

6. **Insular Supplements**: Additional grants for students in islands, with specific amounts.

7. **Income Deductions**: For large families, disabilities, orphans, single-parent families, etc.

8. **Disability Provisions**: Reduction in course load for disability >=65%, and increase in full enrollment grant by 50%.

9. **Application Deadlines**: For all students, from March 19, 2024, to May 10, 2024. Also mentioned a date for university students specifically.

The summary should be 200-300 words. I need to condense all this into a concise, professional text.

Outline the summary:

- Start with an introduction: Announce the grants for the 2024-2025 academic year.

- List eligible programs briefly.

- Explain the financial components: Fixed grants, residence, basic, variable, and excellence grants.

- Mention key requirements: Income and patrimony thresholds, academic performance.

- Highlight additional benefits: Insular supplements, deductions for special circumstances, disability provisions.

- State the application deadlines.

- Keep it in plain text, so use bullet points in narrative form, not actual bullets.

Ensure accuracy: Refer to the data precisely. For example, use the exact euro amounts and thresholds.

Write in English, as specified.

Draft the summary:

"The Spanish Ministry of Education has announced grants for the 2024-2025 academic year. These grants are available for a wide range of post-obligatory and higher education programs, including baccalaureate, vocational training, artistic and sports studies, language courses, and university degrees and master's programs. PhD studies and proprietary titles are excluded.

Financially, the grants consist of several components. There is a fixed income grant of 1,700 euros, a residence grant of 2,500 euros for students living away from home, and a basic grant of 300 euros. Additionally, a variable grant starts at a minimum of 60 euros, and excellence grants are awarded based on academic performance: 50 euros for an average grade of 8.00-8.49, 75 euros for 8.50-8.99, 100 euros for 9.00-9.49, and 125 euros for 9.50 or higher.

Eligibility depends on family income and patrimony. Income thresholds vary by the number of family members; for instance, for a single-member family, the thresholds are 8,843, 13,898, and 14,818 euros. Patrimony limits include 42,900 euros for urban properties and 1,700 euros for movable capital.

Academic requirements must be met. For full-time students, a minimum of 60 credits is required, or 30 for partial enrollment. University access requires a minimum grade of 5.00, and specific credit pass rates are set by field, such as 90% for Arts and Humanities.

Additional supports are available. Insular supplements provide extra funding for students in islands, ranging from 442 to 937 euros. Deductions from income are offered for large families, disabilities, orphans, and single-parent families, with amounts like 525 euros for general large families and up to 4,000 euros for severe disabilities. Students with disabilities of 65% or more can have reduced course loads and a 50% increase in the full enrollment grant.

The application period runs from March 19, 2024, to May 10, 2024, for all students. Ensure to check the official BOE document for complete details and verification."

Check word count: This draft is around 250 words, which fits the 200-300 range.

Ensure all relevant details are covered: I've included programs, financial amounts, thresholds, requirements, supplements, deductions, disability info, and deadlines.

Make it easy to read: Use clear sentences and avoid jargon. Since it's plain text, structure it with paragraphs or coherent flow.

Finalize in plain text: No formatting, just text.

deepseek-chat.text:
Analysis of Spanish Scholarship Data from 2021-2022 to 2025-2026

This report analyzes the provided scholarship data to identify trends in thresholds, amounts, and requirements over the specified academic years.

Overall Stability and Core Consistency
The scholarship framework shows remarkable stability in its core structure. The types of eligible educational programs, basic academic requirements, fixed grant components (basic grant, fixed income component), and excellence award brackets remained completely unchanged from 2021-2022 through 2025-2026.

Significant Trends and Changes

1. Major Increase in Residence Grant Amount
The most significant financial change is the substantial increase in the "cuantia_residencia" (residence grant).
- 2021-2022 and 2022-2023: 1,600.00 euros.
- 2023-2024 and 2024-2025: Increased to 2,500.00 euros.
- 2025-2026: Increased again to 2,700.00 euros.
This represents a total increase of 1,100.00 euros (68.75%) over the period, indicating a strong policy focus on supporting students living away from home.

2. Increase and Reform of Income Thresholds
A major reform occurred in the 2024-2025 academic year, with income thresholds ("umbrales_renta") being increased and presented in a new, clearer tabular format.
- Years 2021-2022, 2022-2023, 2023-2024: Used identical threshold values across three categories (Umbral 1, 2, 3).
- Years 2024-2025 and 2025-2026: All thresholds were raised. For example, for a 1-member household:
  - Old Umbral 1: 8,422.00 euros.
  - New Umbral 1 (2024-25 onward): 8,843.00 euros.
This increase makes more students eligible for scholarships or higher award levels.

3. Expansion of Insular Supplements
A new supplement specifically for Vocational Training (FP) students in the Canary Islands ("suplemento_fp_canarias") was introduced, valued at 300 euros.
- This supplement is present in the data for 2023-2024, 2024-2025, and 2025-2026.
- It is absent from the data for 2021-2022 and 2022-2023.
This shows a targeted effort to support students in specific regions and study paths.

4. Enhancement of Disability Support
The support structure for students with disabilities was slightly expanded.
- For 2021-2022 through 2024-2025: Support specified for disability >= 65%.
- For 2025-2026: An additional increment for disability between 25% and 65% ("incremento_discapacidad_25_65": "25%") appears in the data. This suggests a broadening of eligibility for additional support.

5. Standardization of Application Periods
The application timeline became more standardized and earlier in the year.
- 2021-2022: Had a late, split deadline (October 14 for university students, September 30 for non-university).
- From 2022-2023 onward: A unified application period for all students was established, running from mid/late March to mid-May.
This creates a clearer, predictable schedule for all applicants.

6. Minor Clarifications in Program Listings
The list of eligible programs saw minor textual adjustments, such as "Ciclos de Formación Profesional" instead of "Formación Profesional," but the covered educational levels (baccalaureate, vocational training, university studies, etc.) remained consistent throughout all years.

Summary of Key Trends
- Financial Support Upward Trend: The residence grant saw a major, multi-year increase.
- Eligibility Expansion: Income thresholds were raised in 2024-2025, and disability support was broadened in 2025-2026.
- Targeted Supplements: A new, fixed supplement for Canary Islands FP students was introduced.
- Administrative Simplification: Application periods were unified and standardized, and the presentation of income thresholds was improved.

Conclusion
The scholarship system from 2021-2022 to 2025-2026 demonstrates a clear evolution towards more generous and accessible support. Policymakers have increased key financial amounts, raised eligibility thresholds, added targeted supplements, and streamlined processes. The core academic and merit-based requirements have been kept stable, ensuring consistency for students. The overall direction points to a strengthened financial aid system with a focus on supporting living costs and broadening inclusion.

deepseek-reasoner.text:
Analysis of Scholarship Grants from 2021-2022 to 2025-2026

This report analyzes the evolution of Spanish government scholarship grants over five academic years. The data shows stability in core academic requirements and some grant amounts, with significant increases in the residency grant and income eligibility thresholds in recent years.

Most Significant Overall Trends:
- A substantial increase in the residency grant amount.
- An upward adjustment of income eligibility thresholds, expanding access.
- Stable academic excellence rewards and core fixed grants.
- Incremental improvements in support for students with disabilities and from specific regions.

Detailed Year-by-Year Changes:

1. Fixed Grant Amounts:
- The basic fixed grant for income (cuantia_renta_fija) remained constant at 1,700 euros from 2021-2022 through 2025-2026.
- The basic scholarship (beca_basica) remained constant at 300 euros.
- The minimum variable amount (cuantia_variable_minima) remained constant at 60 euros.

2. Residency Grant (Cuantia Residencia):
This is a key area of change, showing a significant increase to support living costs.
- 2021-2022: 1,600 euros
- 2022-2023: 1,600 euros
- 2023-2024: 2,500 euros (a major increase of 900 euros)
- 2024-2025: 2,500 euros
- 2025-2026: 2,700 euros (a further increase of 200 euros)

3. Academic Excellence Grants (Excelencia):
The structure and amounts for merit-based grants remained completely stable.
- The minimum grant was 50 euros and the maximum was 125 euros every year.
- The grade brackets for awards were identical:
- 8.00-8.49 average: 50 euros
- 8.50-8.99 average: 75 euros
- 9.00-9.49 average: 100 euros
- 9.50+ average: 125 euros

4. Income Eligibility Thresholds (Umbrales Renta):
Thresholds were stable for the first three years but increased significantly for the 2024-2025 and 2025-2026 cycles. The data structure also changed from a "Umbral 1/2/3" object to a simpler table.
- The thresholds for 2021-2022, 2022-2023, and 2023-2024 were identical.
- For 2024-2025 and 2025-2026, new, higher thresholds were applied. For example, for a 1-member household:
- Old Umbral 1: 8,422 euros (through 2023-2024)
- New Umbral 1: 8,843 euros (for 2024-2025 onward)
- Old Umbral 3: 14,112 euros
- New Umbral 3: 14,818 euros
This pattern of increase applies across all family sizes, making more students eligible.

5. Patrimony (Asset) Limits:
All limits remained unchanged throughout the period.
- Urban property limit: 42,900 euros
- Rural property limit: 42,900 euros
- Rural property per member: 13,130 euros
- Movable capital limit: 1,700 euros

6. Academic Requirements:
Core requirements showed no change.
- Full-time credits required: 60
- Part-time credits required: 30
- University access grade required: 5.00
- The percentage of passed credits required by field of study remained the same:
- Arts and Humanities: 90%
- Sciences: 65%
- Social and Legal Sciences: 90%
- Health Sciences: 80%
- Engineering and Architecture: 65%

7. Island Supplements (Suplementos Insulares):
Basic amounts were stable. A new supplement for Vocational Training in the Canary Islands appeared in 2023-2024 and continued.
- The basic insular supplement (442 euros), remote islands supplement (623 euros), and inter-island/peninsula supplements (888 and 937 euros) did not change.
- A new "suplemento_fp_canarias" of 300 euros was introduced in 2023-2024 and continued in 2024-2025 and 2025-2026.

8. Income Deductions:
All deductions for large families, disability, orphans, and single-parent families remained constant in amount throughout the five years.

9. Disability Support:
Core support was stable, with one notable expansion in 2025-2026.
- The reduction in course load requirement for disability >=65% was constant.
- The 50% increase for full enrollment with a disability was constant.
- For 2025-2026 only, a new "incremento_discapacidad_25_65" of 25% was introduced, indicating expanded support for those with a disability between 25% and 65%.

10. Application Deadlines:
The schedule shifted earlier in the calendar year over time.
- The main application window moved from Autumn (Sept-Oct) in 2021-2022 to Spring (March-May) from 2022-2023 onward.
- Example for university students:
- 2021-2022: Deadline was 14 October 2021.
- 2022-2023: Window was 30 March to 12 May 2022.
- 2025-2026: Window is 24 March to 14 May 2025.

Conclusion:
The scholarship system has maintained consistency in rewarding academic merit and supporting students with specific family or disability situations. The most impactful changes are the substantial increase in the residency grant and the raising of income thresholds. These changes directly increase the financial support for living expenses and broaden eligibility to include more students from middle-income families, reflecting a policy shift towards greater inclusiveness and cost-of-living support. Minor positive changes include the new Canary Islands FP supplement and the additional disability increment in the final year.

The residency amount shows clear increases in 2023-2024 and again in 2025-2026, which is a significant trend. 

The income thresholds change in 2024-2025, with a new table format and higher values. That’s another major shift. The academic requirements and excellence grants are stable, but disability support expands in 2025-2026. The island supplements and application deadlines have minor adjustments. 

I’ll structure the report chronologically, highlighting the most notable changes in each section. The user emphasized plain text, so I’ll avoid markdown and use simple bullet points where needed. The goal is to make the trends clear without extra formatting.
